This I'm sure is caused by unsuitable cheap beds that support staff sleep on several times a week, care staff are known to have back problems in later life cheap beds are a huge contribution.

attributes.background: Gift aid is allowable on donations by UK taxpayers. Donations made by non taxpayers, which are often a larger proportion of their income should be encouraged by the government. This small gesture would do so at little cost to the exchequer.

attributes.action: Make the title nutritionist protected
attributes.background: there are many people out there that call them selfs a Nutritionist  however quite a few of them do not hold any degree that gives them the right to be called one let alone to work as one, some people tend to do a few day course which  this will allow them to give nutrition advice out to people
attributes.additional_details:
due to these few days  courses  which people do this causes a knock on effect on our jobs as a nutritionist also this puts people health at risk due to the advice that gets given is incorrect on a few accounts. 

make our title protected like the dietetics is protected

attributes.action: Total referendum votes per geographic area should not be made public.
attributes.background: An individuals vote in the UK is private and is only public if they choose it to be so. This should also apply too the votes of geographic areas and age groups. So this same consideration for privacy of individuals should apply also to geographic areas and age groups.
attributes.additional_details: There is no reason for this information to be made public or even recorded, except for the media to create drama and a division within the country. When a democracy makes a decision, the result should be the nations result and not multiple results specific to areas of the country, or a age group. Focusing what percentage voted what and where, serves no benefit to the nation, and only divides it. So no longer provide the public with a group to attack, when a vote does not go ones way.

attributes.action: Condemn dismissal of judges by Turkish authorities following military coup
attributes.background: Turkish authorities have reacted to the military coup by dismissing nearly 3000 judges around the country. This is a clear victimisation of members of the legal profession and is a disproportionate measure which will impact on administration of justice.

attributes.action: Reinstate the SKILLED MIGRANT VISA to allow commonwealth citizens to work here
attributes.background: For too long COMMONWEALTH citizens (AUS/NZ/CAN etc) have been denied the necessary VISA to come and work in the UK,  denying the UK access to their skills, knowledge and innovation. This is now more necessary than ever in a BREXIT world, and the UK needs to maximise the potential of this resource

attributes.action: Train operators should provide more rolling stock to give all commuters a seat
attributes.background: Train operators habitually operate trains with 4 carriages at peak times causing dangerous levels of overcrowding. Many at non-peak times have up to 12 nearly empty carriages.  They justify this to get rolling stock into position. If they were to invest in enough stock this wouldn't be necessary.
attributes.additional_details: This is self evident to thousands of commuters who use the trains everyday and put up with poor customer service. Part of the franchise should enforce investment in rolling stock to fully meet peak demand.

attributes.action: Stop the rise of youth crime- introduce harsher punishments as a deterrent.
attributes.background: As young people we think youth crime is a problem and more needs to be done about it. We think there should be harsher punishments, especially for repeated offenders as it is unfair all young people and teenagers are labeled 'thugs'.

According to the Daily Mail, under 18s commit a quarter of all crimes.

Statistics on www.gov.uk show that in 2013/14 there were 90,769 offences which resulted in a disposal, and the most common offence was violence against the person.

attributes.action: Make it compulsory for companies to disclose their phone number on contact.
attributes.background: Make it compulsory for companies to disclose their phone number when contacting people. This will give people the chance to call bar nuisance callers directly from home and hopefully bring a stop to the constantly ringing telephone and recorded messages.

attributes.action: Hygiene Facilities in Educational Institutes for our Children
attributes.background: As a grandmother, I struggle at times as my grandchild comes home with her underwear unclean and parents and carers like me would like our children coming home clean and it would be easier for measures to put in place for hygiene purposes.

attributes.action: Redistribute 8 Billion saving from EU to areas with the highest unemployment.
attributes.background: If, we are to leave the EU, and the amount saved is 8 billion pounds. This money should not be swallowed up by tax cuts. It should go to alleviating poverty, in the areas that need it most.

attributes.action: cap the price of household line rental to £10.00 a month.
attributes.background: over £200. per year in line rental charges by service providers, thats before any other charges are made,, it needs to be capped at £10.00.

attributes.action: Immediately raise the minimum wage by 10% to counteract the slump in the pound
attributes.background: People on minimum wage - especially those like myself aged between 18 and 21 - struggled to make ends meet as things were. With all imported products risen in price by 10% due to the slump in the pound, we need some support. We the undersigned call on the government to raise NMW by 10%.
attributes.additional_details: Due to the result of the EU referendum, the pound has dropped by more than 10% against the euro and dollar, increasing the price of all imported goods. It is forecast to drop further. This affects those on lower wages a considerable amount. As I am currently being paid £5.30 an hour, any increase in costs could make me unable to support myself. I fear that I may fall into debt and/or become a burden on the state - this is not something I would like to happen to myself or others in my position.

attributes.action: Change UK Prostitution Laws to be in line with Norway, Sweden, Ireland, France.
attributes.background: The laws around prostitution in the UK are inefficient. Laws around prostitution are in urgent need of reform to ensure this industry doesn't continue to grow.
attributes.additional_details:
Signatories recommend:
- The prostituted be absolved of all criminality
- Investment is made in supporting prostituted persons to exit the sex trade via specialised training, support & health services
- Those at risk of entering prostitution are identified & supported to ensure they have viable career & education options
- The purchase of sexual access to human bodies is criminalised & subject to custodial penalty
- Consultation with Survivor Organisations is undertaken to inform legislation

attributes.action: War and bombing a country or people must be the last option, not the first.
attributes.background:
The Chilcot report has now made it clear "the UK chose to join the invasion of Iraq"  and "Military action at that time was not a last resort".
 
A step by step process should be adopted and implemented before the country goes to war with a country or a people.
attributes.additional_details:
A law should be introduced that ensures that before any violent engagement all other options are exhausted.

A rushed decision should not be made just to silent the public due to an incident or tragic event but rather full procedures should always be followed and the aftermath of the engagement should be given great consideration. 

A vote in the parliament is not enough and can not justify the loss of millions of lives especially when it is apparent like in the Chilcot report that the UK led by Tony Blair was rushed, mislead and ill-prepared for the aftermath. There must be more public involvement in such  decision making. Full responsibility must be put on the Prime Minster of the time.

attributes.action: Re-commit £1 billion in funding for carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology.
attributes.background: Carbon capture and storage (CCS) takes the CO2 produced by power plants and locks it safely away underground. We need Government investment in this technology if the UK is to have any hope of meeting the carbon targets agreed in Paris 2015 and effectively fighting climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK Government has been promising support for CCS since 2007, and in 2012 opened a commercialization "competition" offering £1 billion in venture capital. The funding was withdrawn in November 2015. 

The latest carbon budget will not enable us to meet Paris targets, but CCS can close the gap. The Energy and Climate Change committee and Oxford climate scientist Dr Myles Allen both recommend the Government develop a clear strategy for development of CCS infrastructure and expertise in the UK.

attributes.action: Reduce basic VAT rate to 15%, with further reduction after we have left the EU
attributes.background:
The 'Leave' camp pointed out that the EU sets minimums for VAT rates. The EU basic rate is a minimum of 15% but the UK is currently higher than this, at 20%.

We can't lower it below 15% until we leave the EU, but we *can* lower it to 15%, and then lower it more after we leave the EU
attributes.additional_details:
When the Leave campaign said that while in the EU, we would be unable to control our VAT rates. This is accurate, the EU sets minimums for different categories.

At the moment, we are still in the EU, so have to abide by those rules. 

However, the basic rate of VAT in the UK is currently 20%. This is 5% more than the EU's minimum basic rate of 15% - meaning that we have control over that 5%. Let's get rid of that 5% that we *do* have control of, and once we have left the EU, reduce it further!

attributes.action: STOP the closure of another A&E department in the North East...
attributes.background: Proposals would see A&E departments across Teesside, Durham and Darlington reduced from four to three; putting additional pressure on existing services.  Contradicting the Government’s pledge to ‘improve the health of the country’ and 'making services easier for patients to access'.
attributes.additional_details: The loss of local A&E Services in Hartlepool in 2011, has already caused unnecessary hardship and inconvenience for patients who now travel to Stockton to access A&E.  The road infrastructure (A19 / A66) is inadequate; causing delays for ambulances and patients, potentially causing unnecessary deaths.  The remaining four A&E Departments serve Hartlepool, Stockton, Middlesbrough, Redcar & Cleveland and Darlington, with a total population of 662,800 (2011 Census).

attributes.action: Conscientious objection to military taxation
attributes.background: I no longer want to pay the percentage of taxes that are used to fund military budget. I feel that I am indirectly funding the killing of others. I am morally against this and no longer want to contribute to it through conscientious objection to military taxation.
attributes.additional_details: Conscientious objection to military tax is thought to be an extension to objection to military service. A person with a religious or ethical scruple against taking part in killing people during war is likely to feel no less scruple about paying somebody else to do the killing or about purchasing the mechanism of killing. If a government can respect the right of a person not to participate directly in making war, can it also respect the right of the person to avoid this indirect participation.

attributes.background: According to the board of education, a Level 3 BTEC is equivelent to 3 A- levels. However the amount of work, stress, perserverance and time spent completing A levels is far from on par with that endured from BTEC students.
attributes.additional_details:
'Even students who win places at prestigious Russell Group universities on the back of top results in BTECs are much less likely to gain a first or 2:1 and more than 40 per cent fail to complete their degree course, with many withdrawing because of “academic failure”.'- The Sunday Times.
A- Level students are experienced with high levels of stress and mental endurance due to the courses sat, and so is it just they have to compete for university places that will most probably be dropped out of?

attributes.action: Establish support mechanisms to aid people experiencing abuse due to Brexit.
attributes.background: This petition asks Parliament to urgently recommend putting in place visible resources (web, social & phone) so that members of the public who have been subject to abuse related to Brexit know where to turn to seek advice and the support of concerned and loving members of their community.
attributes.additional_details: Reports of members of the public being subjected to racial or xenophobic abuse has increased noticeably since Brexit. Mechanisms exist to report such hate crimes to the police but there is little visible information connecting the victim or scared member o/t public to volunteer groups representing caring individuals in the community or for those who wish to help, to join together. This issue needs a national voice and to be seen as the responsibility of all ordinary decent civilians.

attributes.action: We will not tolerate public acts of discrimination
attributes.background: We the undersigned call upon HM Govt. to increase punitive measures in response to public acts of aggressive, racial and xenophobic discrimination by 50% for a period of 1 year following the EU Referendum. We believe this will send the clear message that the People of Britain do not tolerate racism.
attributes.additional_details: In the wake of the EU referendum, the risk that racism and bigotry will show itself as an accepted part of our society is higher than ever. By signing this petition, you are calling on our Government to take official steps to show that we are not a racist, bigoted nation and will punish those who seek to do harm to another person because of their culture, religion, country of origin or ethnicity and those who seek to alienate  people along these lines during this political upheaval.

attributes.action: Create a clear legal framework for UK-wide referenda
attributes.background:
The EU Referendum highlighted the problems of using this democratic tool in the U.K,: a small majority, rejection by two home nations, and purely advisory in nature.
This vagueness, uncertainty, and unfairness is plainly unsatisfactory and must be addressed before any future referenda are held.
attributes.additional_details:
It is proposed that a referendum shall be binding on the Government if either of the following criteria is met:
- The votes for the winning side total at least 50% of the total number of those eligible to vote plus one, or
- The winning side is supported by simple majorities in at least three of the four home nations, and by at least two-thirds of the total votes cast.
In all other cases, the Government shall be required to take note of the result of the referendum, but is not bound by it.

attributes.action: Ask public about immigration before negotiating new EU deals
attributes.background: On June 23rd the UK voted to leave the EU. A number of public figures have suggested which factors swayed voters, but the question asked makes it impossible to know public opinion on specific issues. We believe the government cannot claim a mandate to negotiate a new deal without polling.
attributes.additional_details: Some have claimed that immigration was a key factor in the result, but it is impossible to say for certain that a majority of those who voted leave did so to prevent free movement of people. The government should take steps to more effectively gauge public opinion on the nature of Britain’s exit from the EU, so that it can act on facts, not speculation. The issues of environmental legislation, the EU arrest warrant, and the court of human rights should also be included in the poll.

attributes.action: Make it mandatory for every new housing development to include vital services
attributes.background: At the moment in the UK were are facing a crisis - Public services are under strain. School places are in short supply as are doctors and other vital infrastructure. This IS NOT down to immigrants but the failure of councils and central government to ensure developers build these vital services.
attributes.additional_details: Developers need to take responsibility and build essential services into their sprawling developments to aide the struggling public services instead of grabbing as much profit as possible and ignoring the effect their builds are having on local services.

attributes.action: Raise the salary for childcare workers in the early years sector
attributes.background: Childcare workers in the early years have one of the most important jobs in the sector as a whole. They are responsible for the early education, health and wellbeing of children under 5. A rewarding job is there ever was one however this is not reflected in their salaries.
attributes.additional_details: The average full time childcare worker in the early years sector makes less than £1050 per month after deductions. This simply is not reflective of the love, hard work, sacrifice and determination to give the future the best possible start in life. As a childcare worker there is no greater joy than helping a child succeed at being a child and being happy, healthy and confident. But job satisfaction can only take you so far when a roof over your head is needed.

attributes.background: We should bring back half day and Sunday closing to help the economy and give more people family time as more places are open on the Internet

attributes.background: Not all long term medication is free of prescription charges.
attributes.additional_details:
Unless you are receiving benefit, statins and many other long term drugs are subject to a £8.40 charge; per medication. There are many people that are employed but struggle to afford this. These prescription charges represent nothing more than an unfair, stealth tax. 
If the general population were forced to pay an additional £8.40 in tax, every month for life, there would be public uproar! 
This is immoral, fundamentally wrong and needs to be stopped.

attributes.action: Bring back milk for primary school children
attributes.background: When I was younger we always had a small milk bottle with a straw. I think it's really important for children to get calcium and in this busy day and age ensures that all children get some milk.

attributes.action: Before triggering Article 50 an initial UK-EU deal must be handled by Vote Leave
attributes.background: Following the EU referendum, activation of Article 50 of the 2009 Lisbon Treaty should only take place once an initial agreement, outlining key areas of the future relationship, has been reached between the UK and EU. The negotiation should be led by prominent members of the Vote Leave campaign.

attributes.action: A second referendum if UK job losses exceed 12,000 after initiating Article 50.
attributes.background: The referendum campaigns were based on projections that were largely distrusted. A "pain threshold" of 12,000 job losses would be the equivalent of three "Port Talbot Steelworks", the latter creating considerable public out-cry when the potential 4000 job losses were announced in March 2016.
attributes.additional_details: If corporations announce expected job cuts that they will implement if the Article 50 process is initiated, then there will be some threshold over which the electorate and politicians on either side of the debate should be allowed to reconsider their referendum position. Announcements of UK job losses on Friday 24th June already include JP Morgan (4,000), HSBC and Morgan Stanley with the first already matching Port Talbot. A second referendum can help the United Kingdom avoid such job losses.

attributes.action: Set out principles for any negotiation pertaining to leaving the European Union
attributes.background: Parliament should vote on a motion supporting access to European markets, free movement of people, and compatibility with major areas of European law. This being a move to boost confidence for business and markets, and to reassure the European citizens living and working in the UK.
attributes.additional_details: There is currently great uncertainty and anxiety both for business and financial markets, and for the many Europeans who live and work as part of our communities; friends, colleagues and loved ones. Parliament should act to create certainty and confidence, setting out the principles on which any negotiation should be based. This should include the key areas such as free movement, access to markets, and legal compatibility such topics as data protection.

attributes.action: Debate security implications of the removal of U.K. border controls from Calais.
attributes.background: Politicians in France are calling on President Hollande to scrap immigration checks on the French side of the English Channel following UK's vote to leave the EU. We need to know what this means for the UK.

attributes.action: Referendum results less than 60-40 and 75% turnout should go to a second round.
attributes.background: The two most recent referendums (referenda) in the UK did not 'convincingly' reflect the opinion of the general public and did not prove their wishes beyond 'reasonable doubt'.

attributes.action: Electoral vote of acceptance of any Prime minister not Elected
attributes.background: A lot of people vote for the public face of a political party are electing a Prime minister to lead the country, if a political party in Government has to choose a new leader whom will become Prime minister the electorate should have the right approve or reject that person.

attributes.action: Disband the office of the Prime Minister.
attributes.background: Since 1651 we the subjects United Kingdom and the commonwealth have only had a hand full of successful Prime  Ministers, I believe that we should empower our Monarchy with the full powers invested in a head of state

attributes.action: Amend the Human Rights Act to support informed public debate.
attributes.background: Only when we have a clear view of issues can we make informed choice, people cannot make functional choices when they do not know what they are choosing. It should be an offence for those in public office to provide misleading, inaccurate or untruthful information that obfuscates public debate.
attributes.additional_details: I propose an additional article under the UK Human Rights Act which prevents the dumbing down and obfuscation of public debate. It is the duty of public servants to bring clarity and accuracy to public debate to establish objectives and clean information both pro and con. It should be an offence for those in public office to provide misleading, inaccurate or untruthful information that obfuscates public debate.
